column1: Block Belief Propagation for Parameter Learning in Markov Random Fields
You Lu@Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University
column3: Bert Huang@Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University

column1: Traditional learning methods for training Markov random fields require doing inference over all variables to compute the likelihood gradient. The iteration complexity for those methods therefore scales with the size of the graphical models. In this paper
column2: we propose block belief propagation learning (BBPL)
column3: which uses block-coordinate updates of approximate marginals to compute approximate gradients
column4: removing the need to compute inference on the entire graphical model. Thus
column5: the iteration complexity of BBPL does not scale with the size of the graphs. We prove that the method converges to the same solution as that obtained by using full inference per iteration
column7: and we empirically demonstrate its scalability improvements over standard training methods.
